content: How can I help you today?

I've been having trouble sleeping lately. My head is filled with worries about work, and I can't seem to turn my brain off at night. I try to distract myself with my phone, but it just makes things worse. I'm not sure how to get back on track.

Sleep troubles can be so frustrating, especially when worries about work feel overwhelming. It sounds like you've been trying different things to cope, but they haven’t been helping as much as you’d like. Can you tell me more about what’s been on your mind and how these worries have been impacting you?

It’s mostly work. I’m worried about getting fired because I feel like I’m one of the lower-performing employees, and with how the economy is going, layoffs feel inevitable. It’s just this constant loop of stress about providing for my family, paying bills, and what will happen if I lose my job. It’s hard to shut it off at night, and I think it’s affecting my energy and how I connect with my kids too.

That's a lot to carry, and it’s understandable why it’s been so hard to turn off at night. Worries about job security and providing for your family can weigh heavily, especially when it feels like those pressures are seeping into your daily life and interactions with your kids. It sounds like you care deeply about your family and their well-being. How have you been handling all of this stress during the day?

During the day, I just try to keep busy. I focus on work, but it’s hard because the stress follows me there too. I’ll scroll through my phone a lot to try to distract myself, but it doesn’t really help—it just fills my mind with even more things to think about. I don’t feel like I have a good way to cope right now.

It sounds like staying busy and using distractions like your phone have been ways to manage the stress, but they aren’t doing much to ease the weight you’re carrying. It’s tough when nothing seems to calm those constant thoughts, especially when the stress follows you everywhere. What would it feel like if you could find a way to quiet your mind, even for a little while?

Honestly, it feels like it would be a huge relief, but I don't know how to get there. Everything just feels so overwhelming, and I don't even know where to start. I've tried, but nothing seems to stick.

Feeling overwhelmed can make it hard to know where to begin, especially when it seems like you’ve already tried different ways to cope without much success. That sense of relief you’re looking for matters, and the fact that you’re here talking about it shows a lot of strength and determination. What do you think might help you take even a small step toward feeling more in control of your stress or your sleep?

I don’t know—I guess maybe trying something different, but I’m not sure what. It feels like everything I’ve done so far hasn’t really worked, so it’s hard to figure out what could actually make a difference. Honestly, part of me isn’t sure if anything really will.

It sounds like you’re feeling stuck after trying so many things without seeing the results you hoped for, and that can make it hard to feel hopeful about finding something different. At the same time, part of you still seems to want to explore options, even if it feels uncertain right now. What’s kept you motivated to keep searching for ways to feel better, even when it feels difficult?

I guess it’s really my family. I don’t want this stress and sleeplessness to affect them more than it already has. I want to be a good partner and parent, and I don’t like how this is making me feel distant or distracted around them. They deserve better from me.

Your love and commitment to your family really shine through. Despite everything you’re facing, you’re holding onto the desire to be present and connected with them, which is such an important motivator. That desire shows how deeply you care and how much you want to make a positive change. What do you think would make the biggest difference for you—and for them—if things started to shift?

I think just being able to feel more at ease—less stressed and worried all the time—would make the biggest difference. If I could sleep better and stop feeling so on edge, I’d probably have more energy to engage with my kids and be more patient with everything. I just don’t know how to get to that place.

Feeling more at ease and getting better rest could really help you be more present and patient, both for yourself and for your family. It’s clear how much that matters to you. While figuring out how to get there feels uncertain right now, the fact that you’re exploring it shows you’re ready to move forward in some way. Is there anything else you’d like to talk about before discussing how to take steps towards the peace of mind you're looking for?
I think I'm okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
